channel.title: NYT > World

item.title: 8 More Pro-Democracy Lawmakers in Hong Kong May Lose Seats
item.media:description: Protesters set up barriers against the police outside the office of the Chinese liaison in Hong Kong on Sunday.
item.description: A member of a taxi drivers’ association has sought a court ruling on whether the oaths of office comply with new guidelines from Beijing.
item.dc:creator: MICHAEL FORSYTHE and ALAN WONG

item.title: Where the U.S. Is a Rival, Trump Election Is Greeted With a Smile
item.media:description: Presidents Vladimir V. Putin of Russia, left, and Xi Jinping of China have sent postelection messages to Donald J. Trump.
item.description: The election of Donald J. Trump presents an unexpected gift to leaders — political, spiritual and ideological — who resent the encroachment of the West.
item.dc:creator: ANDREW HIGGINS, NEIL MacFARQUHAR and JANE PERLEZ

item.title: Taliban Strike German Consulate in Afghan City of Mazar-i-Sharif
item.description: At least two people were killed and 84 wounded when the insurgents struck with a suicide car bomb near a hotel being used by German diplomats, Afghan officials said.
item.dc:creator: NAJIM RAHIM and FAHIM ABED

item.title: Russian Officials Were in Contact With Trump Allies, Diplomat Says
item.media:description: Donald J. Trump at a campaign event on Monday. A spokesman for President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia said on Wednesday that there were no plans to meet with Mr. Trump in the near future.
item.description: The Foreign Ministry said the deputy foreign minister was referring to contacts with senators who backed Mr. Trump, not campaign representatives.
item.dc:creator: IVAN NECHEPURENKO

item.title: ‘A Moment of Great Peril’: Foreign Observers on Trump’s Success
item.media:description: The front page of a newspaper in Seoul, South Korea, on Thursday.
item.description: A sampling of opinion writing from around the world on the United States presidential election.
item.dc:creator: THE NEW YORK TIMES

item.title: Over 70 Nations Have Been Led by Women. So Why Not the U.S.?
item.media:description: Indira Gandhi at her home in India in 1960. She became her country’s first female prime minister in 1966.
item.description: As barriers have fallen overseas, experts see an underlying bias that has discouraged American women from seeking office, impeding the flow of female presidential candidates.
item.dc:creator: KATRIN BENNHOLD and RICK GLADSTONE
item.category: United Nations Entity for Gender Equality and the Empowerment of Women
Far East, South and Southeast Asia and Pacific Areas

item.title: U.N. Warns of Starvation Peril in Rebel Side of Aleppo
item.media:description: Members of pro-government forces on Thursday in a district of Aleppo, Syria, that had been retaken from rebels.
item.description: Without a pause in fighting to permit emergency food replenishment, a United Nations official said, eastern Aleppo’s 250,000 residents could starve.
item.dc:creator: RICK GLADSTONE

item.title: Memo From Iraq: In Once-Tolerant Mosul, a Social Unraveling That Feels Permanent
item.media:description: People displaced by fighting in Mosul lining up for food distribution at a camp in Hassan Sham, Iraq, on Tuesday. Before the Islamic State’s occupation more than two years ago, Mosul was Iraq’s most diverse city.
item.description: As exiled residents watch the battle for Mosul unfold, many recall a city where religions coexisted peacefully until the American-led invasion.
item.dc:creator: TIM ARANGO
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)

item.title: One More Middle East Conflict: What to Make of Donald Trump
item.media:description: Iraqi forces watched President-elect Donald J. Trump in the village of Arbid on the southern outskirts of Mosul on Wednesday.
item.description: President-elect Trump could lead a reordering of American engagement in the region, and some nations that respect strongmen welcome the change.
item.dc:creator: BEN HUBBARD and ANNE BARNARD

item.title: Abroad in America: In New York, Deep Confusion Stands in Contrast to Elation After Donald Trump’s Win
item.media:description: Television studio sets were dismantled on Wednesday in Times Square after Donald J. Trump’s presidential victory.
item.media:credit: Bryan R. Smith/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.description: Thousands of people, their faces illuminated by Times Square’s advertisements, stood watching and waiting as Mr. Trump steamrollered over Hillary Clinton.
item.dc:creator: DECLAN WALSH

item.title: Mexico Braces for the Fallout of a Trump Presidency
item.media:description: A board displaying the exchange rates of the Mexican peso against the American dollar at a foreign exchange house in Ciudad Juárez, Mexico, on Tuesday.
item.description: For many Mexicans, the election of Donald J. Trump is a harbinger for hard days to come for the country, its economy and even its state of mind.
item.dc:creator: AZAM AHMED, KIRK SEMPLE and PAULINA VILLEGAS

item.title: Clean Energy, Dirty Water: Canada’s Hydroelectric Dams Have a Mercury Problem
item.media:description: The construction site of the hydroelectric facility at Muskrat Falls in Labrador in July. Muskrat Falls will probably be just the first of a series of fights over mercury in Canada, where dams now supply about three-fifths of the country’s electricity.
item.media:credit: Andrew Vaughan/The Canadian Press, via Associated Press
item.description: There have been protests near a project in Labrador, and researchers say problems loom at 22 major dams proposed or under construction close to other indigenous communities.
item.dc:creator: IAN AUSTEN

item.title: What in the World: Forget Movie Stars. In Hong Kong, Exam Tutors Are the Celebrities.
item.media:description: Students waited to attend after-school cramming sessions at a Modern Education tutoring center in Kowloon, Hong Kong. Portraits of tutors line the walls.
item.media:credit: Lam Yik Fei for The New York Times
item.description: To compete for business, cramming centers turn their employees into celebrities, plastering their names and faces on the city’s buses, metro stations and billboards.
item.dc:creator: MIKE IVES

item.title: Despite Vaccination Efforts Measles Kills 350 Children a Day, Report Says
item.description: A study by Unicef, the World Health Organization and other health agencies suggests that vaccines saved 20.3 million young lives between 2000 and 2015, but that there are still problem areas.
item.dc:creator: REUTERS

item.title: Interpol Names Chinese Police Official as Its New President
item.media:description: The election of Meng Hongwei, center, to lead Interpol caused alarm among some rights advocates about attacks on dissidents.
item.description: The election of Meng Hongwei, the first Chinese official to lead Interpol, set off alarm bells among rights activists over the potential misuse of the police organization.
item.dc:creator: THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: Crowds Line Up at India’s Banks to Exchange Banned Rupee Notes
item.description: Prime Minister Narendra Modi’s surprise ban on 500 and 1,000 rupee bills, aimed at tax avoidance and money laundering, is making life difficult for the average Indian.
item.dc:creator: ELLEN BARRY and SUHASINI RAJ

item.title: Alibaba, Amid Intense Hype, Confronts a Slowdown on Singles Day
item.media:description: Jack Ma, center-left, the chairman of the Alibaba Group, and the actor Daniel Craig at a televised gala last November. Mr. Ma brings to the company charisma and an eye for attention rather than a gift for technological wizardry.
item.description: The company turned an obscure holiday into a big shopping event and a symbol of China’s economic rise, but it is under pressure from weak sales growth and a U.S. inquiry.
item.dc:creator: PAUL MOZUR

item.title: Sinosphere: Hong Kong Venue Cancels Screening of Protest Film, Citing Political Concerns
item.media:description: A pro-democracy demonstrator shrouded in tear gas near Hong Kong’s government headquarters in September 2014. An educational group in the city has called off a screening of a film about the protests.
item.description: The abrupt cancellation of the documentary “Raise the Umbrellas” was seen by some in the arts community as evidence of Beijing’s tightening grip on the city.
item.dc:creator: DIDI KIRSTEN TATLOW

item.title: Abe to Meet Trump to Press Japan’s Case on Security and Trade
item.media:description: Prime Minister Shinzo Abe of Japan inspecting troops in Asaka in October.
item.description: He and other leaders in Asia, concerned about North Korea and protectionism, question how involved the next president will be in the region.
item.dc:creator: MOTOKO RICH

item.title: Fugitive Whose Escape From London Prison Had Shades of Alcatraz Is Recaptured
item.media:description: Matthew Baker was arrested on Wednesday.
item.description: One of two inmates who used pillows under their bedsheets to fool guards during a daring breakout was rearrested after three days on the run.
item.dc:creator: DAN BILEFSKY

item.title: U.S. Says It Has Killed 119 Civilians in Iraq and Syria Since 2014
item.description: In each case, officials said, the American military followed the proper procedures and did not violate laws of armed conflict.
item.dc:creator: MICHAEL S. SCHMIDT
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)

item.title: Haiti Opens a Drive to Vaccinate 820,000 as Cholera Flares
item.description: The country, hit hard by Hurricane Matthew last month, has had as many as 3,500 new cases of the disease since the storm’s passage.
item.dc:creator: REUTERS

item.title: Museum Explores Arafat’s Legacy but Leaves Unanswered Questions
item.media:description: Visitors to the Yasir Arafat Museum in the West Bank stood outside the Palestinian leader’s tomb Wednesday, a day before the museum’s public opening.
item.description: The Yasir Arafat Museum treads a fine line, honoring the Palestinian narrative while dealing dispassionately with some of the movement’s more awkward periods.
item.dc:creator: ISABEL KERSHNER

item.title: Trilobites: Narwhals, Tusked Whales of the Arctic, See With Sound. Really Well.
item.media:description: Two male narwhals sparred near Baffin Island, Canada. Researchers found that the whales have exceptional echolocation abilities.
item.description: Researchers tracked narwhals and found that they reconstruct their underwater world with more resolution that most other animals on the planet.
item.dc:creator: JOANNA KLEIN

item.title: Trump’s Victory, on Front Pages Worldwide
item.media:description: Wednesday’s front pages of the British newspapers The Sun, The Times and The Evening Standard featured Donald J. Trump’s victory in the United States presidential election.
item.description: Newspapers across the globe scrambled to create front pages befitting the day’s place in history.
item.dc:creator: DANIEL VICTOR

item.title: Wireless Brain-Spine Connection Overcomes Paralysis in Monkey
item.media:description: Grégoire Courtine holding a silicon model of a primate’s brain and an implant. The brain-spine interface uses a microelectrode array like this one to detect spiking activity of the brain’s motor cortex.
item.media:credit: Alain Herzog/Swiss Federal Institute of Technology, Lausanne
item.description: A wireless connection between the brain and spinal cord allowed monkeys with a partially severed spinal cord to direct the movement of a paralyzed leg with brain signals.
item.dc:creator: JAMES GORMAN

item.title: As Americans Look North to Flee Donald Trump, Canada Peers Back in Worry
item.description: Canadians reacted to the election of Mr. Trump with concerns, anxiety and a whiff of pride.
item.dc:creator: IAN AUSTEN and DAN LEVIN

item.title: Sharbat Gula, Famed ‘Afghan Girl,’ Is Welcomed Back to Afghanistan
item.media:description: Sharbat Gula, left on the cover of National Geographic in 1985, and then nearly two decades later, after she was featured in a story in the magazine about being reunited with the photographer.
item.media:credit: Steve McCurry/National Geographic Society, via Agence France-Presse
item.description: Ms. Gula, who was pictured as a young girl on the cover of National Geographic in 1984, had been arrested in Pakistan and deported.
item.dc:creator: ROD NORDLAND

item.title: Wuzhen Journal: Ancient Town in China Enjoys Profitable Rebirth as a ‘Beautiful Stage’
item.media:description: Canals in Wuzhen, a town of about 50,000 that has become a wildly successful example of tourism development in China. Nearly seven million tourists visit every year.
item.media:credit: Gilles Sabrié for The New York Times
item.description: Wuzhen, drawing millions of tourists each year, has become a wildly successful example of importing arts and theater into selfie-ready backdrops of flowing canals and stone bridges.
item.dc:creator: AMY QIN

item.title: Tram Derails in Croydon, Near London, Killing at Least 7
item.media:description: Members of the emergency services worked after a tram overturned, injuring and trapping some passengers in Croydon, a suburb south of London, on Wednesday.
item.description: The police said that the driver had been arrested after the deadly accident in Croydon, south of the British capital.
item.dc:creator: STEPHEN CASTLE

item.title: Asia, a Target of Trump’s Criticism, Greets His Election With Caution
item.media:description: An election event at the United States Embassy in Beijing on Wednesday.
item.description: Donald J. Trump has had harsh words for China and other nations, but the question for the region now is how much of that rhetoric he will act on.
item.dc:creator: KEITH BRADSHER
item.category: Far East, South and Southeast Asia and Pacific Areas
United States Defense and Military Forces

item.title: The Interpreter: Uncertainty Over Donald Trump’s Foreign Policy Risks Global Instability
item.media:description: Donald J. Trump, in Virginia Beach, Va., in September.
item.media:credit: Eric Thayer for The New York Times
item.description: World leaders and policy experts are unable to deduce a coherent worldview from the president-elect’s often conflicting pronouncements.
item.dc:creator: MAX FISHER
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces

item.title: ‘Brexit’ Proved to Be Sign of Things to Come in U.S.
item.media:description: Nigel Farage, the leader of the U.K. Independence Party, right, campaigned in August with Donald J. Trump in Jackson, Miss.
item.description: There are remarkable parallels between the British decision to leave the European Union and the triumph of Donald J. Trump.
item.dc:creator: STEVEN ERLANGER

item.title: The Interpreter: Trump’s Victory and the Rise of White Populism
item.media:description: Supporters of Donald J. Trump celebrating in Columbus, Ohio, on Wednesday.
item.media:credit: Maddie McGarvey for The New York Times
item.description: The president-elect has tapped into a sense of alienation and loss of status among poorer white voters, a sentiment that exists in other countries, too.
item.dc:creator: AMANDA TAUB

item.title: Trump Business Partner Is Philippines’ New Trade Envoy to U.S.
item.media:description: President Rodrigo Duterte of the Philippines, left, at the main international airport serving Manila on Wednesday.
item.description: The chairman of the company that is building the Trump Tower in metropolitan Manila will be the special envoy for trade, investment and economic affairs.
item.dc:creator: RICHARD C. PADDOCK

item.title: Sinosphere: How a Word, ‘Chee-na,’ Renewed a Crisis Between Beijing and Hong Kong
item.media:description: Sixtus Leung, a pro-democracy politician, used a word for China that is widely considered derogatory in his oath of office last month in Hong Kong. He also wore a banner reading “Hong Kong Is Not China.”
item.description: With its echoes of Japan’s wartime occupation, an alternative term for China has emerged as a fresh irritant in relations between the semiautonomous city and the mainland.
item.dc:creator: MIKE IVES

item.title: Why Did Beijing Slap Down Hong Kong Separatists? To Make a Point
item.media:description: President Xi Jinping in Beijing in October. China’s recent interference in the seating of Hong Kong’s legislature is a sign of how strongly Mr. Xi sees issues of sovereignty.
item.description: There were other less draconian ways to resolve Hong Kong’s oath-taking impasse. But President Xi Jinping takes a hard line on challenges to sovereignty.
item.dc:creator: CHRIS BUCKLEY

item.title: For Russia and Putin, a Surprise Gift From America
item.media:description: Portraits of the president-elect, Donald J. Trump, and President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia in Moscow on Wednesday.
item.description: In some ways, the election’s outcome was less important to President Vladimir V. Putin than the chance for Moscow to use the campaign as evidence of Western decline.
item.dc:creator: NEIL MacFARQUHAR

item.title: Across the World, Shock and Uncertainty at Trump’s Victory
item.media:description: News on the United States election in Mexico City. President Enrique Peña Nieto of Mexico congratulated the American people on their election and stressed his nation’s willingness to work with them.
item.description: After a stunning upset in the American presidential election, nations braced for the possibility of an upending of the global order.
item.dc:creator: THE NEW YORK TIMES

item.title: Sinosphere: Chinese Journalists Get an Exhilarating Look at the U.S. Election
item.media:description: Voters casting their ballots in New York City on Tuesday. A Chinese journalist observing the election expressed surprise at how seriously Americans took their votes.
item.media:credit: George Etheredge for The New York Times
item.description: A small group of Chinese reporters has been traveling across America, courtesy of the State Department, and hoping their articles pass muster with China’s censors.
item.dc:creator: ANDREW JACOBS

item.title: Editorial: Doors Slam Shut for Afghan Refugees
item.media:description: An Afghan Internally Displaced Person (IDP) waits to receive rations at the United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees (UNHCR) donation camp in Kabul, Afghanistan, 08 November 2016.
item.description: The international community is failing to address Afghanistan’s worsening refugee crisis.
item.dc:creator: THE EDITORIAL BOARD
item.category: United Nations High Commission for Refugees
Middle East and Africa Migrant Crisis

item.title: Editorial: China Bullies Hong Kong
item.media:description: Sixtus Leung, center, with glasses, being blocked from taking his seat in the Hong Kong legislature.
item.description: Beijing’s tightening hand is undermining Hong Kong’s enviable economic model.
item.dc:creator: THE EDITORIAL BOARD

item.title: Op-Ed Contributor: After These Days of Rage
item.description: Extremes of inequality lie at the root of voters’ anger. We can’t repair the political center without fixing the economics of that.
item.dc:creator: ALAN JOHNSON

item.title: Postcard From the Hajj: A Pilgrim’s Progress: Checking Mecca Off My Bucket List
item.media:description: “Pilgrims surprised me with their warmth.”
item.description: This reporter’s long-dreamed-of journey to explore the heart of Islam revealed surprises, debunked stereotypes and produced one stunning bird video.
item.dc:creator: DIAA HADID

item.title: Postscript: One Year Later, a Tip About a Border Crossing Pays Off
item.media:description: Laborers transported ammonium nitrate at the crossing from Akcakale, Turkey, into Syria in April 2015. The compound, a common fertilizer, has been used by terrorists to create explosives.
item.media:credit: Diego Ibarra Sanchez for The New York Times
item.description: How New York Times reporting may have made the Middle East just a little bit safer.
item.dc:creator: BEN HUBBARD and KARAM SHOUMALI
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)

item.title: Turkish Dam Project Threatens to Submerge Thousands of Years of History
item.media:description: The Turkish town of Hasankeyf will be submerged under 200 feet of water after a hydroelectric dam now under construction is completed.
item.media:credit: Samuel Aranda for The New York Times
item.description: A contentious dam project that dates to the 1950s is more than 80 percent complete, and the filling of a reservoir will swamp much of the town of Hasankeyf.
item.dc:creator: TIM ARANGO

item.title: Devanampattinam Journal: Mortal to Divine and Back: India’s Transgender Goddesses
item.description: During the 10-day Hindu festival Mayana Kollai, the troubles of transgender women are distant as they transform into the deities they worship and are revered by villagers.
item.dc:creator: Photographs by CANDACE FEIT
